nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: The Trigger Moment
nodes.text: The door slams hard enough to shake the frame. Your co-parent storms into the room, holding an unpacked school bag. Your child watches from the hallway, frozen in place.

choices.label: Stay still and take one slow breath.
choices.text: You ground yourself before reacting.

choices.label: React immediately and raise your voice.
choices.text: You snap back and demand to know why they are slamming doors.

choices.label: Send the child to their room gently.
choices.text: You turn and quietly tell the child that the adults need a minute to talk.

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: The Explosion
nodes.text: The co-parent's voice is sharp and brittle. They accuse you of forgetting the homework folder and say they feel humiliated in front of the school staff.

choices.label: Use a grounding phrase.
choices.text: You say you can see they are upset and suggest talking about it without yelling.

choices.label: Deflect responsibility.
choices.text: You point out that they could have checked the bag before leaving.

choices.label: Acknowledge the intensity, not the blame.
choices.text: You name that the situation sounds very stressful and invite a slower pace.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: The Turning Point
nodes.text: The co-parent exhales sharply and paces the room. The anger is about more than one forgotten folder. The whole week has been tight and brittle. You can feel the moment tipping toward either repair or escalation.

choices.label: Offer a reset moment.
choices.text: You suggest pausing for a moment and offer water or a short break before continuing.

choices.label: Push back on their tone.
choices.text: You point out that they do not get to speak to you this way and insist they calm down first.

choices.label: Shift toward collaboration.
choices.text: You gently pivot toward solving the morning routine together so this does not repeat.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: A Breath Before Act 2
nodes.text: The air eases just slightly. There is still tension, but the explosion is no longer at its peak. There is a narrow path toward de-escalation.

choices.label: Continue to Act 2 — Emotional De-escalation
choices.text: You move carefully into the next phase of the conversation.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You pause the scene here.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Stepping Out of the Storm
nodes.text: You both end up in the kitchen, a few steps away from the slammed door. The immediate shock is passing, but emotions are still high.

choices.label: Take a short time-out and name it.
choices.text: You calmly say you need two minutes to breathe and will come back to talk.

choices.label: Invite the co-parent to sit down with you.
choices.text: You suggest sitting at the table to talk instead of arguing in the hallway.

choices.label: Keep following them and continue the argument.
choices.text: You stay close and keep arguing, hoping to force a resolution immediately.

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: Underneath the Anger
nodes.text: The co-parent sits or paces more slowly. They admit they feel judged by teachers and afraid the child will think they are careless.

choices.label: Reflect the feeling underneath.
choices.text: You name that it sounds like they feel ashamed and scared of being seen as a bad parent.

choices.label: Correct the story with facts.
choices.text: You point out that everyone forgets things sometimes and that the teachers understand.

choices.label: Minimize their experience.
choices.text: You say they are overreacting and that it is not a big deal.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Choosing a De-escalation Strategy
nodes.text: You can feel the emotional temperature shifting. This is your chance to choose how the rest of the conversation will unfold.

choices.label: Use we language and shared goals.
choices.text: You emphasise that you both care about the child feeling safe and supported.

choices.label: Focus on proving you are right.
choices.text: You double down on explaining that you did nothing wrong and they are overreacting.

choices.label: Agree on a signal for future time-outs.
choices.text: You propose a simple phrase or gesture you can both use next time things feel too intense.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Act 2 — Emotional De-escalation
nodes.text: The volume has dropped. The words are still serious, but no longer explosive. You are slowly steering the interaction back toward stability.

choices.label: Continue to Act 3 — Problem Solving
choices.text: You shift from emotion to practical planning.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You pause the scene at this stage.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: From Blame to Planning
nodes.text: With emotions lowered, attention turns back to the morning routine. The question is how to prevent this kind of scramble next time.

choices.label: Co-create a simple checklist.
choices.text: You suggest making a shared list for the school bag that both homes can use.

choices.label: Assign responsibility to one parent only.
choices.text: You push for the other parent to take full responsibility for the school bag.

choices.label: Postpone problem solving.
choices.text: You suggest leaving the detailed planning for another day.

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: Negotiating the Details
nodes.text: The co-parent reacts to your suggestion. They may relax into the idea of a shared list or push back, worried about one more thing to track.

choices.label: Offer to try the new plan for a short trial period.
choices.text: You propose testing the routine for a few weeks and then checking in together.

choices.label: Insist on your way as the only option.
choices.text: You press that your plan is the only logical solution.

choices.label: Invite their ideas first.
choices.text: You ask what would make the plan feel manageable for them.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Naming the Agreement Out Loud
nodes.text: Together you land on at least one small, concrete change to the routine. Saying it out loud helps anchor it in reality.

choices.label: Repeat the agreement clearly.
choices.text: You restate who will do what and when, making sure it is simple enough to remember.

choices.label: Keep the plan vague and unwritten.
choices.text: You nod along but do not clearly repeat or write anything down.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Act 3 — From Fire to Framework
nodes.text: The conversation has moved from accusation to at least one small agreement. It is not perfect, but it is a start.

choices.label: Continue to Act 4 — Repair with the Child
choices.text: You turn your attention to how the child experienced all of this.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You pause the scene at this stage.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Checking on the Child
nodes.text: The house is quieter. Your child is in their room or nearby, having watched at least part of the conflict.

choices.label: Approach with gentle curiosity.
choices.text: You sit nearby and invite them to share how they are feeling without pushing.

choices.label: Act as if nothing happened.
choices.text: You switch topics and suggest doing homework or chores without naming the conflict.

choices.label: Over-explain the adult details.
choices.text: You launch into a long explanation about who was right and wrong in the argument.

nodes.speaker: Child
nodes.title: Hearing Their Experience
nodes.text: The child admits they felt scared when voices were loud and worried that they did something wrong.

choices.label: Offer a clear repair message.
choices.text: You reassure them that the argument was between adults and that they are not to blame.

choices.label: Minimise their feelings.
choices.text: You tell them it was not that bad and they should not be so sensitive.

choices.label: Blame the co-parent in front of the child.
choices.text: You say the other parent had a bad day and overreacted.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Co-regulation
nodes.text: You notice the child's shoulders slowly dropping or staying tense, depending on how the repair went. There is a chance to co-regulate together.

choices.label: Do a calm activity together.
choices.text: You suggest a simple, soothing activity like drawing, reading or a short walk.

choices.label: End the conversation quickly.
choices.text: You say everything is fine now and move on immediately.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Act 4 — Repair in Progress
nodes.text: The child has at least seen that the storm does not last forever. How you repair today will shape how safe they feel tomorrow.

choices.label: Continue to Act 5 — Reflection and Next Time
choices.text: Later, you take a moment to look back at what happened.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You end the scene here.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Looking Back at the Conflict
nodes.text: The house is quiet. You replay the sequence in your mind: the slam, the sharp words, the choices you made along the way.

choices.label: Notice what went better than usual.
choices.text: You deliberately list small ways you de-escalated or repaired, even if the conflict was still hard.

choices.label: Focus only on what went wrong.
choices.text: You dwell on mistakes and imagine future conflicts going exactly the same way.

choices.label: Recognise you may need extra support.
choices.text: You notice patterns that might be easier to change with outside help, like therapy or mediation.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Planning the Next Time
nodes.text: You imagine the next difficult moment: raised voices, tight schedules, a child in the middle. This time, you picture specific tools you could reach for.

choices.label: Commit to one concrete de-escalation skill.
choices.text: You choose a simple skill, like taking a breath before answering or using we language, and decide to practice it.

choices.label: Plan a short check-in with the co-parent.
choices.text: You decide to propose a calm check-in later, when no one is triggered, to talk about how arguments affect the child.

choices.label: Do nothing different and hope things improve on their own.
choices.text: You leave the future to chance and make no specific plan.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Act 5 — Integrating the Lesson
nodes.text: Conflicts will still happen. But each time you de-escalate instead of escalate, you teach the child something powerful about safety, emotion and repair.

choices.label: Return to menu.
choices.text: You close this scene and return to the main menu.

choices.label: Replay from the trigger moment.
choices.text: You jump back to the start to experiment with different choices.
